commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Rock alternative  (5)
2. Source of schadenfreude?  (6)
3. Smack in the middle of a crowd, in brief?  (3)
4. Bond classification  (6)(4)
5. Like Manhattan in the 80s and 90s?  (6)


PAPER
GERMAN
PDA
ACTION HERO
UPTOWN
Lovely tribute to Mel Blanc. Well done.

What a great themed Monday following the challenging Sunday puzzle we had. 

In the early 90’s my late mother let us watch all the Looney Toons we could get.  She even bought us shirts.  My personal favorite was the Pepe Le Pew.
A couple of really fun days in a row. Yes, I loved the Pig Latin, but the emus ate my commendation. So here I am to say it again.

This was a charming crossword tribute to the great Mel Blanc, whose comic voice characterizations were a major part of my childhood.

My favorite BUGSBUNNY ELMERFUDD episode involved Elmer tricking Bugs into switching roles.  At the end Bugs, posing as Elmer, was arrested, and Elmer, in his bunny disguise said, “I may be a scwewy wabbit but I’m not going to Alcatraz.”  It may have been the only time Elmer got the better of the wily rabbit. Pure gold.

I only checked the byline at the end of the solve, but all along I just knew there was a brilliant brain behind it. It turns out there were two!

My middle brother and I, as children, would always enact the opening of the Bugs Bunny cartoon.
"Is there a doctor in the house?"
[A shadow raises its hand in the audience] "Yes, I'm a doctor!"
"What's up doc?"

Well, that brother became a physician. Now, as adults, we have some *real* fun with that script.:-)

Thank you, ACME and Christina for sparking nice memories, and for sparkling the Monday puzzle. 
I wish it had been Sunday-sized!

I didn't have any cash to buy the 'Looney Tunes' memorabilia. I gave the seller a Blanc check.

(That pun Bugs people.)

This was a great puzzle! I loved the theme. I got almost all of the acrosses, a rarity for me, that I got to skip over many of the downs. So, I am glad I read Wordplay and saw that we had yipes and yowie! I liked those two in the same puzzle.
Thanks, you two! What a fun Monday!
What a super tribute! The "Man of 1,000 voices" did, in fact, around 400 distinct characters, for 3,000 cartoons in all.
No No NO!  Mel Blanc did not voice Elmer Fudd.  How did this pass even basic editing?  “You can look it up” - it’s Arthur Q. Bryan.
I enjoyed this but got completely stuck on WOULDI. Can some kind soul please explain why that precedes “try me”? I am being dense.

What a relief to be thinking about the time not that long ago when life made sense.  Bugs Bunny and Elmer Fudd and Woody Woodpecker and Pepe le Pew and all the rest seem like mental giants now.

Thanks Andrea and Christina, I needed that.
That's all, folks!
Wow. What would life be without Mel Blanc?

Grew up without tv service so movies and babysitting or staying at a friends were my exposure to looney tunes. Got Daffy right off the bat. Had to get a few downs to realize Woody but the rest of his voices were very easy. Still love Bugs and Elmer. 2:38 under my average. Nice trip down memory lane
Great fun! Thank you!
A very enjoyable trip back to my youth. Thanks for that!

No problems, and quite a fun blast from the past, but, alas, my favorite characters did not make the cut. My absolute top choice is that pesky alien that keeps attempting to blow up the Earth, and kept getting foiled by Duck Dodgers or Bugs, or both: Marvin, the Martian. My next group is that southwestern pair of Wile E. and the Roadrunner. Taz is up there, and Gossamer was unique. When I was at Kansas U, we had a convocation where Chuck Jones, the director of many Looney Tunes cartoons was the speaker, and he brought a few of them along, and also introduced us to "The Dot and the Line: a romance in lower mathematics", which I'm attaching here (don't worry, no calculating involved, but it does contain some visual and other puns): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FpFXlfybnfg The writer of the story is the author of "The Phantom Tollbooth", Norton Juster. Anyway, thank you Acme and Christina, it was an absolute treat!
Woody Woodpecker was most notably voiced by producer Walter Lantz's wife Grace Lantz, not Mel Blanc. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grace_Stafford.

I have to gripe a bit about 67A…
This is the second time in a short span that I’ve seen the NYT crossword use “lase” as a verb in this way: for a clue that should solve to “tase” but with an L, implying that someone is being “zapped” by a laser. First off, “laser” is derived from an acronym—it’s not defined as “a thing that performs the verb ‘lase’.” After lasers became better-known, people DID construct a verb “lase” backwards from the noun laser, but it means to emit light, not to “zap” anything. These “lase” clues have been poorly constructed. Not a big problem in this easy Monday puzzle, but it’s still sloppy and inaccurate.

What an awesome tribute to the talented Mel Blanc! I was always partial to Tweety Bird and Sylvester as well as Wile E and Roadrunner. Beep beep!  😍  Thank you, ACME and Christina for the perfect start to our week!

Not alot to say today but it was kind of fun that I filled out this puzzle in an UBER on the way home from seeing Cabaret. Not super meta, but maybe a wee bit. The happy music went off just as he pulled up to our apartment. ☺️

Especially liked the 29 down clue for tip! Good one!! 

Fun puzzle. Cute theme!

I was about to protest the notion that “pound cake” means you use a pound of every ingredient, but it turns out that’s actually true! Or at least it used to be; modern recipes finesse the quantities. I was always under the impression that the name derived from the cake’s density/ heaviness.

I still say a pound of sugar sounds a bit extreme.
Me to yesterday's crossword: "You know, this means war"
Why did filling in my name as the answer to 20 Across give me such a thrill?

Sam,

Mel Blanc voiced around 3,000 cartoons, not cartoon characters.
Is it just me, or was there a mistake in today's Mini? Karaoke accessories surely are MICS, not MIKES?

I did this with no reveals, only ever manage that on Mondays. Hooray for me!

So I'm old enough to know the cartoons here, although I don't really remember Pepe LePew. I got him entirely with crossers.

I've never had a BLT that was crunchy; chewy bacon, not crispy, is the preference.
Not sure what REFI means? REF I?

Quite delightful.
What a fun start to the week.  I quite like feeling nostalgic.

Nit, to be read in the voice of Bugs Bunny:

“Clear component of blood”, in vivo, is plasma, not serum.
Yeah, you get serum as a clear component when a tube of blood clots.
Yeah, we still say things like “serum creatinine” and mean both the lab value found in the serum in the tube, and the (plasma) value in the patient.
Conclusion: clue is okay but not great.

(Will the emus allow me in today?)
A delightful puzzle! I thought for sure, though, that there would be some sort of revealer that read "That's all, folks," since it's actually engraved on his gravestone.

Bugs THE Bunny
Daffy THE Duck
Elmer THE Fudd
Woody THE Woodpecker

Get it right, please.

(Nope, sorry, I'm just starting a no-sleep Monday with the appropriate grouchiness. Y'all got it right. A good week to all.)

Random thoughts:
•	Strong fauna presence with DUCK, WOODPECKER, and BUNNY in the theme answers, plus SWAN, MULE, TEACUP dog, not to mention the magic dragon.
•	WOODY WOODPECKER is just a gorgeous grid spanner.  I wonder if Andrea/Christina were also considering SYLVESTER THE CAT, also at 15 letters.
•	The difference between early- and late-week clues: For HOARD today, [Stow away, big-time]; for the same word a week ago Sunday, [Mega-store?]
•	Fun fact – Mel’s birth surname was Blank.  He changed it to Blanc after a teacher told him he would amount to nothing and be like his name, a “blank”.  (Wikipedia)
•	Lovely PuzzPair© of IHOP and BUGS BUNNY.
•	Lovely theme echo in [Mont Blanc, e.g.].  (Pointed out by Rex Parker.) 

The theme got me thinking about how, as a kid, I loved watching cartoons on tv, and left me with a warm feeling that has lingered.  Thank you, Andrea and Christina!

It's amazing how those characters and their catch phrases are so easy to recall, when other memories are not. Is it because of repetition? The fun we had while watching? I don't know, but they are indelible.
Really nice Monday! Came in about 3 minutes slower than average. Just enough resistance!

Fun Monday puzzle and a pretty smooth solve by a couple of my favorite constructors (always glad to see another ACME enterprise). With my memory, I needed a few crosses to remember a couple of the theme answers, but they came quickly. One puzzle find today was inspired by Elmer Fudd. A Wednesday from November 24, 1999 by Greg Staples. Three theme answers in that one, with Elmer in the clue for each of them: BEVEWYVEWYQUIET ISNTSHEWOVEWY IMHUNTINGWABBIT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/24/1999&g=38&d=A Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ....

Probably a lifetime-fastest solve for me, coming in at 6:01. Can't imagine ever besting that, simply based on my typing skills (or lack thereof). Am always impressed by folks who can do/enter these in under three minutes.

A very solid puzzle, though even on Monday I'd prefer a theme that's more than just a collection of related names.

I assume it has been used before, but I especially liked "Good thing that comes to those who wait?" for TIP.

A nice MELlow Monday puzzle, no intimidating BLANC spaces.

Yes, nostalgic fun, but I don't want to hear any young whipper-snappers moaning about baby boomer references. 😉  Mel Blanc and his characters are to cartoons what Shakespeare is to theatre ---timeless, classic.

So far, we're just seeing some larger waves from Hurricane Erin. Not expecting any big impacts, but North Carolina shore might get whalloped, or whapped or whupped.
The next one, if it develops into Hurricane Ferdinand as the models predict, might hit near here over Labor Day weekend.

Enjoyed the puzzle!
Mel Blanc is my hero! Among his many voices is Barney Rubble.  And I've been wondering lately did Barney have a job?

Another piece of trivia about Mel is his getting injured in a car crash on "Dead Man's Curve" in LA. Which put him in a coma.
During recovery in hospital he continued to record Barney's lines.
Silly Wabbits!! Great fun...Grazie!
Sufferin' succotash! Was I the only one who noticed Mont Blanc as a bonus tribute item? Nice of the EUROS to name an ALP after him.

Happy Monday, everyone. This was a nice easy palate cleanser after a challenging weekend! I wasn’t allowed to watch cartoons as a child, my mother deemed them too violent, but even I had little trouble with these, especially when I had a few crosses filled in.

Could have been improved by working MEL BLANC in as a revealer maybe?  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
A little weak as a theme for something as iconic as Looney Tunes, but nothing *terrible* per se.
Now I’m thinking about fun ways to have a Looney Tunes themed Sunday puzzle (Wile E Coyote chasing the Roadrunner around the grid with some rebus action)… but alas it’s 9 am on a Monday and I have to write work emails instead of learning puzzle construction.  Boo.

A nice Monday puzzle.  Smooth sailing; little to no reason for complaint (I hope).

And who doesn't love Mel Blanc and the hundreds of characters he voiced???
Sufferin’ succotash!  I knew I shoulda taken that left turn at Albuquerque.  What a maroon.  Well, so long suckers.
At first I mistook Sylvester for DAFFY DUCK. 9 letters, it fit... Thufferin' thuccotash!
I confidently entered SYLVESTER as the answer for 18A. Guess I was thinking of “Sufferin’ succotash!!”

ACME and Iverson-- perfect combo for a Monday puzzle, with the sole drawback of the solve being OTS!  (Over Too Soon!)

I don't know if they are on the LOONEY TUNES list (we're supposed to know the cartoon collections by syndicate/publisher name?)...but for my money Foghorn Leghorn and the baby Chicken Hawk, not to mention the Roadrunner and Wile E Coyote !! are the best cartoons.
Oh, wait.  What about the Huckleberry Hound lot?  Dudley DoRight and Nell! And Boris Badinoff and Natasha! 
Oh, and George of the Jungle!  (Watch out for that tree!)
Rocky the Squirrel and that Moose who went to Whatsamatta U?

(I never warmed up to Felix the Cat--too fake.  TweetyBird needed to be let out of his cage, never to be seen again...)
Maybe I should get on with Monday chores here...

my thoughts that no one asked for this Monday: i've really come around on the early week puzzles. when i started my NYT crossword journey a couple years ago, i could usually manage Monday & Tuesday, Wednesday was a toss-up, and had no hope for the rest of the week. after getting more familiar, the puzzles became more accessible, and i really relished the tough end-of-week/weekend puzzles, and thought of the early weeks as  placeholders until the good stuff arrived. maybe my ego abated a little bit, but now i find the soothing solve of the early week puzzles really enjoyable, and can appreciate the construction of them, without it being tied to the difficulty of the clues. 

thanks for the great puzzle, Andrea!

The last word across in today's Mini-Crossword was misspelled, IMO with a different homophone.

The actual answer should have been spelled with a C, then pluralized. The other spelling is informal and therefore way more uncommon.

My encyclopedic knowledge of cartoons finally comes in handy! I knew this day would come!

On a related note, I recently discovered that there's a channel devoted entirely to old cartoons. It's called MeTV Toons and it lives two channels above that one channel that only shows the Rockford Files in a wonky aspect ratio. Every ad on it is for a prescription drug with three X's in its name.

My only complaint is that they left out my two favorite Mel Blanc characters: Mulan and Jasmine(a name which means, coincidentally, "I'm hunting wabbits".)

Seriously fun puzzle and wonderful tribute to a man who left an amazing legacy!

On an arguably related note, does anybody remember the '70s film "What's Up, Doc?", a screwball romcom starring Barbra Streisand and Ryan O'Neal? 

Great supporting cast included Kenneth Mars, Madeline Kahn and Austin Pendleton("My Cousin Vinny").

I loved it and was surprised to find out just now how much critics and audiences enjoyed it as well.

Such a fun and nostalgic way to start the week - thank you Andrea & Christina! 

It brought back a sweet memory of receiving a favorite gift as a child -- a stuffed Bugs Bunny with a pull cord that had him repeat over and over, "Eh, what's up doc?" that I never seemed to tire of listening to (much to my parents' chagrin).
Woody woodpecker cries AND Barber of Seville playing in my brain as I solved this one with glee - fine start to the week! (Brain is quieter now we're done 😃)

oh how i amuse myself!

living in the bay area, when i saw 1D, i immediately entered WAYMO, bc our streets are littered with these auto-driving cars

other than that, happy monday, everyone!

So much fun. What a treat of a stroll down memory lane. The saccharine laden tosh they put on for kids now can’t hold a candle to the cartoons of the 60’s. My personal favourite was Tom and Jerry, always the last programme before kids tv ended for the night. At 5:45! None of this 24 hour nonsense. Bah humbug, grumble grouse.

Oh the crossword. Lovely. Light and sweet and a perfect way to ease into the new week.

At last, constructors from my generation! Easy breezy solve, bringing back the sounds and images of my childhood toons. I loved working on this puzzle.
Re 17A--there is an expression "there's been a birth in my family." So, YES, new parents can celebrate a birth that happened already.

It was fun to solve this while listening to WOODY WOODPECKER hammering away at a tree outside. 

I do love having the pileateds around.
3:25!  Not a PB, but definitely up there.  Super smooth clue flow and appreciate the shout out to Mel Blanc!

What a lovely tribute to the Man of a Thousand Voices. Those cartoons still are the best ever made, with their wacky humour, fluid visuals, and of course, Mel Blanc's incredible talent. There is a special place in my heart for "One Froggy Evening", and for Marvin the Martian. "Give me back my space modulator!"

Thanks to the constructors, and thank you, Mel.
"I knew I shoudda toined left at Albaquoique!"

Doesn't  Daffy Duck pronounce it  more like more like "dethpicable" (that is, with a lisp) than "despicable"? That honestly threw me for a loop the first pass through - I thought there might be another character. Especially when later encountering clues with "wabbit" and "ze".

I hate to pop the balloon, but Elmer Fudd was one of the few Looney Tunes characters Mel Blanc did not voice. Only Blanc received screen credit, but Fudd was voiced by Arthur Q. Bryan (1899-1959). Bryan was a popular radio actor, most notably on "Fibber McGee and Molly."

Late puzzle find - the most amazing one I've ever encountered. A Sunday from June 11, 2017 by Charles M. Deber with the title: "Think twice." The clue for every theme answer in that one simply cross-referenced two other theme answers. Some examples; 22a - "7- and 112-Across" BASEBALLTERMS 7a - "Example of 22- and of 65-Across" HOMER 112a - "Example of 83- and 22-Across" DIAMOND 65a - "7- and 31-Across" FAMOUSPOETS 31a - "Example of 65-Across and 39-Down" FROST 39d -"31-Across and 15-Down" WEATHERWORDS 15d - "Example of 39- and 34-Down" SHOWER 34d - "93-Across and 15-Down" BRIDALTHINGS 93a - "Example of 34-Down and 108-Across" TRAIN 108a - "93 and 116 across" - MEANSOFTRAVEL And there were more and more and more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/11/2017&g=112&d=A ...

I just did Sunday puzzle. 
I’m not a fan of Sunday in general because the grid is just too big (too much time to solve). Plus. Very difficult on a standard phone. 

That said. 
I was shocked. Shocked. At all the “readers pick” hate.  

Because I am a solving savant.  I never look at the Sunday title because it would make the solve “too easy.”  

That said. Even after the most obvious author/ title/theme  giveaway of all time, this community brought the hate. 

I’ll never figure this place out.  Sure. The grid wasn’t super clean. But coming up with that many “double sided” themers was pretty inspired, methinks.  

Obviously. The mob’s mileage did vary.  

Eeshyay
So fun!! Easy, breezy, no furrowed brow—just what I want from a Monday puzzle!

Looney Tunes

      Porky
        Pig

That’s all folks! 🎶
Incredibly fun one today, loved it!

Well, I found out just before doing the puzzle last night that Terrance Stamp had died, and I'm going to use the excuse that the clue for 5 Across mentions a kangaroo to post this clip from Priscilla, Queen of the Desert. About one minute in wordplayers will see why I think it's particularly apt for us. If you're not a fan of RuPaul, this clip is probably not for you. https://youtu.be/kevJJDQloNE?si=qbOrUy7zlaIiIrsi

Thank you *very* much Andrea & Christina for a very fun trip down memory lane. Like other folks have already mentioned, I was hooked on Looney Tunes as a kid, and I'll take any chance to revisit Bugs, Daffy, and the rest! (I wasn't a big fan of Woody Woodpecker, though; I think it's because he seemed more obnoxious than the other characters.) Mel Blanc was certainly a genius, too. Has anyone already mentioned the story of how his son was able to rouse him from his coma? I first heard it on Radio Lab many years ago, and it's absolutely fascinating! (My apologies if this was already posted.) https://www.openculture.com/2013/05/the_strange_day_when_bugs_bunny_saved_the_life_of_mel_blanc.html
What a lovely tribute to the very talented Mel Blanc!
Mel Blanc was certainly a once-in-a-lifetime talent.  And he did voice Woody Woodpecker, but I think only for 1 year.  Grace Stafford was the voice for 41 years.

My note on 10D:

The French name for pound cake is *quatre-quarts*, or "four quarters"--equal quantities (by weight) of butter, sugar, eggs, and flour--nothing else. Traditionally, no leavening is used. Also, a traditional way of measuring the ingredients is to put the eggs you are planning to use on one side of a (balance) scale, and weigh the other three ingredients to match.

The recipe I use is pretty much that standard, but I've tweaked the ratio of sugar to flour (7:6) to reflect contemporary American tastes. Also, I put a little leavening in.

BILL'S DETROIT-STYLE POUND CAKE:

6.5 oz. unsalted butter
7 oz. sugar
3/8 tsp. (kosher) salt
flavorings--a little vanilla might be nice, or some almond extract, or some lemon zest, or orange*, or  . . .
3 whole eggs plus as many yolks to make 6.5 oz. (weigh them!)
6 oz. A.P. flour
1 tsp. baking powder

In a stand mixer, cream butter with sugar, salt, and flavorings until light and fluffy. Meanwhile, sift together flour and baking powder. Add about half the egg mixture to the butter, then stir in the flour, then the rest of the eggs. Mix just until incorporated.

Put the batter into to a greased and floured loaf pan. Bake in a low-medium oven (325° or so) until a tester comes out clean.

Would now be a good time to serve it with some grilled peaches and some whipped mascarpone?

*Chef's tip--if using zest, grind it with the sugar for a few seconds in a food processor, to release the aromatic oils.

(Hi, @MOL, and @ Heidi!)

…and now I have the Woody Woodpecker song stuck in my head!

(Thanks for the fun solve anyway. ;))
Could simply not complete today’s puzzle without enjoying a bowl off cereal. That is how I used to watch morning cartoons.
Well, suffering’ succotash, that was a fun puzzle. Very Monday friendly. I enjoy childhood nostalgia and those characters have a permanent space in my brain.
Really interesting to hear the puzzle was rejected twice. Do you get feedback on why?
Not only was the puzzle fun to solve, but Sam's article was fun to read. Thanks, all.

The Looney Tunes spans generations. I happened upon it while with my 17 year old, who definitely did not grow up with them, and we both laughed uproariously. So, so good.

And as others have said, a lovely, smooth puzzle!

As a student at Northwestern University (class of '92), the film club put on a "Warnerfest" just before finals week: Three solid hours of back-to-back Warner Brothers cartoons. We all enjoyed singing along to "What's Opera, Doc" and calling out in unison with Daffy as Robin Hood:

"Ho! Ha ha! Guard! Turn! Parry! Dodge! Spin! Ha! Thrust!"

Over thirty years later I still have that memorized. I put it into YouTube and it pulled up an excerpt from the correct video, which made me very happy.
Mics is not mikes.
Really delightful Monday puzzle. I especially loved it because my 4 year old grandson was visiting recently and we watched a lot of Looney Tunes cartoons. He loved them ❤️
New Personal Best! And totally fun while doing it!

Loved it! Nostalgic for my childhood Woody Woodpecker doll -- one of those with a string to pull so he'd say HahahaHAha 😂. I know it drove my parents bonkers but they bought it!

Of course only one arm bone would fit in the space, so obvious, but "inside bone"? One hopes all one's bones are inside.

If they meant "medial" to the radius... that's true only in "anatomical position". In regular life it is rarely found in that position and tends to be held either posterior or lateral to the radius.
Fun puzzle, especially for a Monday. It brought back memories.
I'M A CHICKEN HAWK!

My favorite used-before clues from last week:

[Collector's item, informally?]  (3)
[New Jersey?]  (4)


IOU
CALF

Lewis,
At least one ostensible Manhattan resident 
did not understand yesterday's #5.
@Barry Ancona. As did an Australian until I remembered street labelling conventions in N.Y.

Patrick,

(1) You get a pass, even if it is The New York Times crossword. (2) I do not know the street labelling conventions in Sydney.

@Barry Ancona The term Uptown can refer to Upper Manhattan, but is often used more generally for neighborhoods above 59th Street; in the broader definition, Uptown encompasses Upper Manhattan. (which would include streets numbered in the 80s and 90s.) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Manhattan

@Lewis

Totally agree with you this time.

@BA
Your comment reminds me of the first time I went for jury duty in Manhattan and during voir dire the defense attorney asked me where I lived. My apartment was in Carnegie Hill, so I responded, “on the upper east side”, to which he retorted, “Do you live in Harlem?”  I learned something about neighborhoods that day.

SP,

Amen!

(Will this fine Monday puzzle be deemed "unfair" 
by/for solvers not familiar with Mel Blanc?)

@Barry Ancona

Hopefully not, but I am expecting to get comments about Pepe LePew’s long history of documented sexual harassment (see wiki article which will be attached) and how he should never be included in any puzzle ever again.

@SP Pepe is historical. If he’s to be cast out then I doubt Nero would ever make it in. 😀

It’s not like the puzzle is raising statues.
@SPYes, that was so cute!!

@Barry Ancona

Why do you feel it's necessary to take another swipe at V? Wasn't one enough?
@Ιασων that was a joke bc it's a cartoon, not a real person

@Marshall Walthew

Should be Alcatwaz. Stupid autocorrect and even stupider failure to proofread.

@Mike

You have a Daffy sense of humor.
@Mike that’s some funny money!

@Mike
Looks like his nibs is going to milk those duds to get some snickers, and dots okay with me.

@Mike

You could try to steal it, but you might end up in a cel.

He was a pioneer in Voice Over IP applications.

(That's Intellectual Property, you wascal.)
@Mike Suffering succotash! That was Tweety kind of you

@Mike
You belong in a cel, yourself!

@Mike
I tried to come up with a response, but drew a blank.  I'll listen to some car tunes while I drive to the store; maybe that will help.

@El Gran Jugador I did look it up. Did you? Fudd was originally voiced by Mel Blanc between 1937 and 1938, Danny Webb between 1938 and 1939 (only in Cinderella Meets Fella (1938) and Believe It or Else (1939)), Roy Rogers in 1938, only doing a singing voice in A Feud There Was, and radio actor Arthur Q. Bryan between 1939 and 1959, but on seven occasions during Bryan's lifetime, the voice was provided by Blanc: in Good Night Elmer (1940), Blanc did Elmer's crying; in The Wacky Wabbit (1942), Blanc did Fudd's screams of fear; in The Big Snooze (1946), Blanc spoke as Fudd crying, "Oh, agony, agony!"; in The Scarlet Pumpernickel (1950), only a single line was needed, and bringing in Bryan was not cost effective; in Quack Shot (1954), Blanc did Elmer's Peter Lorre-esque laugh after he is shot in the face by his toy battleship; in Wideo Wabbit, Blanc did Elmer's cry of pain; and in What's Opera, Doc?, Elmer's furious scream "SMOG!" was dubbed by Blanc, although Bryan had voiced the rest of the part. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmer_Fudd#Portrayal
@Steve L I’m assuming Elmer Fudd said “I’m hunting wabbits” between 1937 and 1938.  None of your other citations are relevant.

@Sara W

I think we owed it to Mel.
ELMER FUDD is the "I'm hunting wabbits" speaker regardless of who voiced that line.

@Sara W

Steve's L post is chock full of relevant citations, all showing that the "I'm hunting wabbits" speaker [ELMERFUDD] was voiced many times by Mel Blanc. Regardless of whether Mel Blanc voiced that exact line. (To Barry's succinct point.)

Petrol,

"WOULD I [be interested]?"
@Barry Ancona I still don’t get it …

@Aaron,

Good point. It’s a stretch, but a possible scenario would be:

Person 1: “Would you (fill in the blank)?”
Person 2: “WOULD I? Try me!”

Awkward. I agree, might have been clued better.

@dutchiris
I had the very same feeling…and a brief, but appreciated, warm sense of nostalgia. Sigh.

@JayTee
I remember being ecstatic about "The Dot and the Line" when I was in college.  Boy, is THAT ever an Oldie-but-Goodie.

@MRR

There are surgeries and other treatments that involve lasers, and people refer to that process of being lasered informally as being zapped. So, in my opinion, the clue is fine.
@JayTee I don’t know where you’ve ever heard this, but in the many laproscopic surgeries I’ve had not once did anyone refer to using a surgical laser as “zapping” me.

@MRR

But I've heard people say "I got zapped". I did say "informally". Professional people, unless you're very comfortable with them and know them well enough to joke around a bit, aren't going to say "zap" or any form thereof.

@MRR I tried “nuke” first thinking it might be referring to a microwave 🤷🏼‍♀️ I always figure if the clue gets me to the answer eventually, it works. I never expect clues to be exact definitions, simply a hint. YMMV

@JayTee
I think MRR is saying that "to lase" means to emit light, not to strike with a laser beam. A laser may zap someone, but it doesn't lase them.

@Bill

I don't know what else you'd call it. I had holes burned through my irises using a laser, to prevent narrow-angle glaucoma. I would personally call that being lased or lasered. I'd also say my eyes got zapped. I just know that my eye pressures have been fine ever since that was done 10 to 12 years ago.

@JayTee
Glad your eyes are OK now! They were lasered.

@MRR
Have to disagree…dermatologists use the word lase  as it  refers to using the laser ( many treatments involve this tool.
@MRR, back-constructions are part of the language too. My only gripe here is the not-so-age-old LASE/TASE ambiguity-- I need to just start leaving the first letter blank.
@Rachel I’m not suggesting back-constructs aren’t part of the language—I’m pointing out that THIS one doesn’t mean “to hit something with a laser”; it means “to emit light like a laser”.

@Jack McCullough I wasn’t suggesting that being an acronym makes the clue not work; I was pointing out that, in this case, the back-construction “lase” doesn’t mean “use a laser on,” but rather “emit light like a laser”.
@JayTee It’s quite ironic that you say you don’t know what else you’d call it… just before providing a second option for what you’d call it.

@RI guy
Oh, like repo. I wonder if this is slang and if these shortenings are used in formal settings?
I wonder if anyone has investigated why one culture abbreviates words such a lot, and another does not?
Not exactly a PhD thesis, but curious all the same!

@Jane Wheelaghan

A lot of the time it's used as a kind of verbal shorthand, and I've seen refi used in discussions with a banker or realtor. Repo is a similar case, but in a more casual way. You might say your car was repossessed, but you might call the guy who did it the repo man.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: a Thursday from October 31, 2013 by David Kwong. This was pretty amazing. One down clue and answer in the very middle of the puzzle: 23 down: "Things worth looking into?" MIRRORS And then all the other theme answers were pairs of across answers with the second answer referencing that MIRRORS answer. One example with the clues; 1a - "Universal Studios role of 1941" WOLFMAN 8a - "1-Across, in 23-Down" NAMFLOW And some other pairs, clued similarly. MONSTER / RETSNOM PHANTOM / MOTNAHP But then the last ones at the very bottom of the puzzle; 64a -"Universal Studios role of 1931" DRACULA 65a - "64-Across, in 23-Down :" And that answer was " " (just blank squares) Thought that was pretty clever. @Amy
Both "mike" and "mic" are informal versions of "microphone." "Mike" is certainly less common, but that does not mean it's incorrect. A short visit to any dictionary would tell you that "mike" is an acceptable abbreviation, as either a verb or a noun.

@Amy
The dictionary begs to differ…short for microphones is mikes.

@Amy - This comes up almost every time MIKE is clued the way it was today. 

One time someone was adamant that nobody has ever used MIKE and it is always MIC. But I am old enough to remember when MIKE was standard and then MIc began to come into use. (I worked as an electronics tech in HS and into my college years and was an audio junkie and musician. We used Mike. I remember resisting the use of MIc when it began to appear, but eventually accepting it.)

These people insisted I was wrong, even though I was telling them how the word was used back then. 

Someone, I think it was Barry A., even posted an article that was about the two words and how it was that MIc came to be the preferred term, replacing the previously standard MIKE. 

In spite of our telling them how we actually used the word back in the '60s, and an article discussing and documenting the history of the two words, they still insisted that nobody had ever used MIKE and that nobody ever would, and that we were wrong and the clue/answer was wrong. There's just no getting through to some people, I guess.

They were, of course not even born in the '60s, so they would have no memory of this.

@CaptainQuahog, we old fogies are so frequently discounted when we share our own PERSONAL experience with usage! It's quite annoying to be told that something I actually lived never happened!

I tire of hauling out my stock answer that language always has and always will evolve, and thank goodness it does. Life would be a mite duller if not.

@CaptainQuahog

@Steve L Others, including Blanc, voiced early versions of the character (such as Egghead) but the definitive Fudd, the one who liked to hunt "wabbits," was Arthur Bryan's creation from 1940. After Bryan's death in 1959, Mel Blanc did not want to take over as Fudd because he didn't create the voice. The clue is in error and I stand by that.

@laviolet

OK, fine.  So now he's just the Man of 999 Voices.

Let me take another tack.  I don't think you get how crossword clues work.

If Blanc ever voiced Fudd, the clue is accurate.  He doesn't have to be the definitive voice of Fudd.  The clue doesn't require that.  The clue doesn't require the most obvious answer, either (although it wouldn't have really been obvious to most of us).  It doesn't require the answer that is right most of the time.  

The clue was ["I'm hunting wabbits" speaker voiced by Mel Blanc].  Fudd was that speaker.  Blanc voiced Fudd several times.  It matters not whether Blanc ever voiced Fudd saying "I'm hunting wabbits" even.  It just requires that Fudd was the one who said that, and Blanc voiced Fudd.  (Even if he did it once.)

The clue is fine.  Don't like it if you don't want to.

"Blanc voiced Fudd several times." Not in any of the theatrical cartoons, only in the later television specials. Look up Blanc's IMDB page.  Any time people hear "wabbits" in the classic cartoons, they're hearing Bryan. Fudd is not Blanc's character; that's just a well-documented fact. Get somebody at NYT to contact Jerry Beck, the leading animation historian, and see what he thinks. 

As for your argument that the clue is correct even if Blanc voiced Fudd only once, I doubt that's what Will had in mind. 

I've been doing NYT crosswords for at least 25 years and can do most Saturdays without looking anything up. I'd say I have a decent idea of how crossword clues work.

@laviolet

"Mel Blanc is most famous for voicing Bugs Bunny and Porky Pig, but he also provided the voice of Elmer Fudd in several Looney Tunes shorts. While Arthur Q. Bryan was the primary voice actor for Elmer Fudd, Blanc occasionally stepped in to voice the character, particularly for specific sounds like crying or screams, or when Bryan was unavailable."
